text:
Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers
                              

 












Fake Jobs: Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers





Share with your network!
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
February 21, 2019


                Proofpoint Threat Insight Team
  
        

 Overview
Since the middle of 2018, Proofpoint has been tracking campaigns abusing legitimate messaging services, offering fake jobs, and repeatedly following up via email to ultimately deliver the More_eggs backdoor.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: These campaigns primarily targeted US companies in various industries including retail, entertainment, pharmacy, and others that commonly employ online payments, such as online shopping portals.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The actor sending these campaigns attempts to establish rapport with potential victims by abusing LinkedIn’s direct messaging service.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: In direct follow-up emails, the actor pretends to be from a staffing company with an offer of employment.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: In many cases, the actor supports the campaigns with fake websites that impersonate legitimate staffing companies.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: These websites, however, host the malicious payloads.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: In other cases, the actor uses a range of malicious attachments to distribute More_eggs.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: We also believe that the same actor recently sent related campaigns, first noted by Brian Krebs, targeting anti-money laundering officers at financial institutions [1].
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Delivery
We have observed a number of variations among the campaigns, but most share common characteristics.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: While not exhaustive, the general flow as well as specific examples of these attacks are described below.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Initially the actor uses a fraudulent, but legitimately created LinkedIn profile to initiate contact with individuals at the targeted company by sending invitations with a short message (Figure 1).
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: This appears as a benign email with the subject “Hi
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: [Name], please add me to your professional network”.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Figure 1: Example of initial message in which attackers abuse LinkedIn messaging.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Within a week, the actor sends a direct email to the target’s work address reminding the recipient about the prior attempt to communicate on LinkedIn (Figure 2).
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: It uses the target’s professional title, as it appears on LinkedIn, as the subject, and often suggests the recipient click on a link to see the noted job description.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
In other cases, this actor used an attached PDF with embedded URLs or other malicious attachments.

Figure 2: Example follow up email to the target’s work address, with a malicious URL.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The URLs link to a landing page that spoofs a real talent and staffing management company, using stolen branding to enhance the legitimacy of the campaigns (Figure 3).
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The landing page initiates a download of a Microsoft Word file (Figure 4) with malicious macros created with Taurus Builder (described below).
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: If the recipient enables macros, the “More_eggs” payload will be downloaded and executed.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: In other cases, the landing page may initiate the download of a JScript loader instead, but this intermediate malware still ultimately results in the delivery of More_eggs.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Figure 3: Example of a landing page for the URL included in email using stolen branding and a lookalike domain for a talent management agency.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
This one specifically initiates a download of a malicious Microsoft Word document.

Figure 4: Example malicious Microsoft Word document that uses macros to download More_eggs.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: As noted, some campaigns also used malicious attachments instead of URLs in the email.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Figure 5 shows an example of one such attachment, a PDF with a link to a spoofed landing page like that shown in Figure 3.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Figure 5: Example PDF attachment  that contains a malicious URL.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Variations
These campaigns demonstrated considerable variability, with the actor frequently changing delivery methods and more.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Examples of the types of techniques used by the actor to deliver the final More_eggs payload include:
URL linking to a landing page that initiates the download for an intermediate JScript loader or Microsoft Word document with macros or exploits
URL shortener redirecting to the same landing page
PDF attachment with a URL linking to the same landing page
Password-protected Microsoft Word attachment with macros that download More_eggs
Completely benign emails without a malicious attachment or URL attempting to further establish rapport (Figure 6)

Figure 6: Example of a benign email designed to establish rapport with potential victims
Tools
This actor uses a variety of tools to distribute malware.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: We briefly describe three such tools below.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Taurus Builder
We use this name to describe a tool used to create malicious documents.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: We believe Taurus builder was purchased on underground crime forums.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Notably, documents created with this builder use the CMSTP bypass as described in [2].
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Both Palo Alto Networks [3] and QuoScient
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: [4] have previously described documents created with this kit.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
VenomKit
We use this name to describe documents generated by a builder purchased from the same seller as Taurus builder.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Depending on the variant it may exploit CVE-2017-0199, CVE-2017-8570, CVE-2017-8759, CVE-2017-11882, CVE-2018-0802, and/or CVE-2018-8174.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Notably, VenomKit often also uses the same CMSTP bypass as Taurus.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Documents from this kit have previously been discussed by Quoscient [4].
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
More_eggs
More_eggs is malware written in JScript used in these campaigns and others.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: It is often used as a downloader.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: In addition to its ability to download additional payloads, More_eggs has extensive capabilities to profile the infected machine.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: The malware was first documented by Trend Micro [5].
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Overlaps with Anti-Money Laundering Campaign
Brian Krebs wrote about a related campaign that targeted anti-money laundering officers at financial institutions that we believe may have been sent by the same actor.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Although targeting and the final payload were different in the campaign he described, key similarities to campaigns describe above included:
The use of a similar PDF email attachment to the PDFs used in the Fake Jobs campaigns
The PDFs of both the anti-money laundering campaign and the Fake Jobs campaigns at one point included URLs hosted on the same domain
Large Follow-up Spam Campaign
Note: As we were finalizing this report we observed a larger than usual campaign from this actor on Feb 21, 2019, from random senders, with a malicious URL in the email.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text:
Conclusion
As threat actors continue to turn away from very large-scale “spray and pray” campaigns and focus on persistent infections with downloaders, RATs, bankers, and other malware, increasingly sophisticated social engineering and stealthy malware are making their way into a range of campaigns.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: This actor provides compelling examples of these new approaches, using LinkedIn scraping, multi-vector and multistep contacts with recipients, personalized lures, and varied attack techniques to distribute the More_eggs downloader, which in turn can distribute the malware of their choice based on system profiles transmitted to the threat actor.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: In response to the increasing effectiveness of layered defenses and end user education efforts, we can expect more threat actors to adopt approaches that improve the effectiveness of their lures and increase the likelihood of high-quality infections.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Note: We have informed all affected parties about the abuse of their services and brands in these campaigns.
source: Fake Jobs_ Campaigns Delivering More_eggs Backdoor via Fake Job Offers _ Proofpoint US.html

text: Last updated: Nov 05, 2021
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: RansomwareThreat ResearchSummaryRecently, FireEye Managed Defense detected and responded to a FIN6 intrusion at a customer within the engineering industry, which seemed out of character due to FIN6’s historical targeting of payment card data.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The intent of the intrusion was initially unclear because the customer did not have or process payment card data.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Fortunately, every investigation conducted by Managed Defense or Mandiant includes analysts from our FireEye Advanced Practices team who help correlate activity observed in our hundreds of investigations and voluminous threat intelligence holdings.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Our team quickly linked this activity with some recent Mandiant investigations and enabled us to determine that FIN6 has expanded their criminal enterprise to deploy ransomware in an attempt to further monetize their access to compromised entities.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: This blog post details the latest FIN6 tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), including ties to the use of LockerGoga and Ryuk ransomware families.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: It also highlights how early detection and response combined with threat intelligence gives Managed Defense customers a decisive advantage in stopping intruders before their goals manifest.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: In this instance, Managed Defense thwarted a potentially destructive attack that could have cost our customer millions  of dollars due to business disruption.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Detection and ResponseManaged Defense worked in tandem with the customer’s security team to acquire relevant log data, share findings from system analysis, and answer critical investigative questions.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The customer was also undergoing a penetration test, so additional scrutiny was required in order to delineate between authorized testing activity and unauthorized activity attributed to FIN6.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Our customer provided valuable insight into the role and importance of affected systems in preparation for entering Rapid Response.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Rapid Response is a service offering that delivers incident response support to Managed Defense customers.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: As with any incident response service, the primary goal is to scope of the nature of the identified malicious activity and to assist our customers with a successful eradication event to eliminate the presence of adversaries.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Managed Defense, utilizing FireEye Endpoint Security technology, detected and responded to the threat activity identified within the customer’s environment.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The subsequent investigation revealed FIN6 was in the initial phase of an intrusion using stolen credentials, Cobalt Strike, Metasploit, and publicly available tools such as Adfind and 7-Zip to conduct internal reconnaissance, compress data, and aid their overall mission.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Managed Defense investigated activity on two systems initially detected as compromised by FireEye Endpoint Security, the industry leading endpoint security solution that was ranked as the most effective endpoint detection and response (EDR) solution.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The activity was detected by comprehensive real time methodology signatures designed to identify the most evasive adversary techniques.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Pivoting from these initial leads, analysts identified suspicious SMB connections and Windows Registry artifacts that indicated the attacker had installed malicious Windows services to execute PowerShell commands on remote systems.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Windows Event Log entries revealed the user account details responsible for the service installation and provided additional IOCs (Indicators of Compromise) to assist Managed Defense in scoping the compromise and identifying other systems accessed by FIN6.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Managed Defense utilized Windows Registry Shellbag entries to reconstruct FIN6’s actions on compromised systems that were consistent with lateral movement.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Attack LifecycleInitial Compromise, Establish Foothold, and Escalate PrivilegesTo initially gain access to the environment, Managed Defense analysts identified that FIN6 compromised an internet facing system.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Following the compromise of this system, analysts identified FIN6 leveraged stolen credentials to move laterally within the environment using the Windows’
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).Following the RDP connection to systems, FIN6 used two different techniques to establish a foothold:First technique: FIN6 used PowerShell to execute an encoded command.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The command consisted of a byte array containing a base64 encoded payload shown in Figure 1.  Figure 1: Base64 encoded commandThe encoded payload was a Cobalt Strike httpsstager that was injected into the PowerShell process that ran the command.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The Cobalt Strike httpsstager was configured to download a second payload from hxxps://176.126.85[.]207:443/7sJh.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye retrieved this resource and determined it was a shellcode payload configured to download a third payload from hxxps://176.126.85[.]207/ca.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye was unable to determine the final payload due to it no longer being hosted at the time of analysis.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Second technique: FIN6 also leveraged the creation of Windows services (named with a random 16-character string such as IXiCDtPbtGWnrAGQ) to execute encoded PowerShell commands.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The randomly named service is a by-product of using Metasploit, which creates the 16-character service by default.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The encoded command contained a Metasploit reverse HTTP shellcode payload stored in a byte-array like the first technique.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The Metasploit reverse HTTP payload was configured to communicate with the command and control (C2) IP address 176.126.85[.]207 with a randomly named resource such as “/ilX9zObq6LleAF8BBdsdHwRjapd8_1Tl4Y-9Rc6hMbPXHPgVTWTtb0xfb7BpIyC1Lia31F5gCN_btvkad7aR2JF5ySRLZmTtY” over TCP port 443.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: This C2 URL contained shellcode that would make an HTTPS request for an additional download.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: To achieve privilege escalation within the environment, FIN6 utilized a named pipe impersonation technique included within the Metasploit framework that allows for SYSTEM-level privilege escalation.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Internal Reconnaissance and Lateral MovementFIN6 conducted internal reconnaissance with a Windows batch file leveraging Adfind to query Active Directory, then 7-zip to compress the results for exfiltration:adfind.exe -f (objectcategory=person) >  ad_users.txtadfind.exe -f
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: objectcategory=computer > ad_computers.txtadfind.exe -f
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: (objectcategory=organizationalUnit) > ad_ous.txtadfind.exe -subnets -f
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: (objectCategory=subnet) > ad_subnets.txtadfind.exe -f
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: "(objectcategory=group)"
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: > ad_group.txtadfind.exe -gcb -sc trustdmp >  ad_trustdmp.txt7.exe a -mx3 ad.7z
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: ad_*The outputs of the batch file included Active Directory users, computers, organizational units, subnets, groups, and trusts.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: With these outputs, FIN6 was able to identify user accounts that could access additional hosts in the domain.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: For lateral movement, FIN6 used another set of compromised credentials with membership to additional groups in the domain to RDP to other hosts.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Maintain PresenceWithin two hours of the initial detection, the systems were contained using FireEye Endpoint Security.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Through containment, attacker access to the systems was denied while valuable forensic evidence remained intact for remote analysis.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Due to Managed Defense’s Rapid Response and containment, FIN6 was unable to maintain presence or achieve their objective.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Through separate Mandiant Incident Response investigations, FireEye has observed FIN6 conducting intrusions to deploy either Ryuk or LockerGoga ransomware.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The investigations observed FIN6 using similar tools, tactics, and procedures that were observed by FireEye Managed Defense during the earlier phases of the attack lifecycle.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant observed additional indicators from the later attack lifecycle phases.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Lateral MovementFIN6 used encoded PowerShell commands to install Cobalt Strike on compromised systems.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The attacker made use of Cobalt Strike’s “psexec” lateral movement command to create a Windows service named with a random 16-character string on the target system and execute encoded PowerShell.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: In some cases, the encoded PowerShell commands were used to download and execute content hosted on the paste site hxxps://pastebin[.]com.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Complete MissionFIN6 also moved laterally to servers in the environment using RDP and configured them as malware “distribution” servers.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: The distribution servers were used to stage the LockerGoga ransomware, additional utilities, and deployment scripts to automate installation of the ransomware.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant identified a utility script named kill.bat that was run on systems in the environment.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: This script contained a series of anti-forensics and other commands intended to disable antivirus and destabilize the operating system.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN6 automated the deployment of kill.bat and the LockerGoga ransomware using batch script files.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN6 created a number of BAT files on the malware distribution servers with the naming convention xaa.bat, xab.bat, xac.bat, etc.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: These BAT files contained psexec commands to connect to remote systems and deploy kill.bat along with LockerGoga.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: FIN6 renamed the psexec service name to “mstdc” in order to masquerade as the legitimate Windows executable “msdtc.”
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Example strings from the deployment BAT files are shown in Figure 2.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: To ensure a high success rate, the attacker used compromised domain administrator credentials.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Domain administrators have complete control over Windows systems in an Active Directory environment.start copy svchost.exe \\10.1.1.1\c$\windows\temp\start psexec.exe \\10.1.1.1 -u domain\domainadmin -p "password" -d -h -r mstdc -s -accepteula -nobanner c:\windows\temp\svchost.exeFigure 2: Strings from deployment BAT filesRansomwareRyuk is a ransomware that uses a combination of public and symmetric-key cryptography to encrypt files on the host computer.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: LockerGoga is ransomware that uses 1024-bit RSA and 128-bit AES encryption to encrypt files and leaves ransom notes in the root directory and shared desktop directory.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Additional information about Ryuk and LockerGoga is available on the FireEye Intelligence portal: 18-00015730 and 19-00002005AttributionFIN6 has traditionally conducted intrusions targeting payment card data from Point-of-Sale (POS) or eCommerce systems.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: This incident’s targeting of the engineering industry would be inconsistent with that objective.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: However, we have recently identified multiple targeted Ryuk and LockerGoga ransomware incidents showing ties to FIN6, through both Mandiant incident response investigations and FireEye Intelligence research into threats impacting other organizations.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: We have traced these intrusions back to July 2018, and they have reportedly cost victims tens of millions of dollars.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: As the frequency of these intrusions deploying ransomware have increased, the cadence of activity traditionally attributed to FIN6—intrusions targeting point-of-sale (POS) environments, deploying TRINITY malware and sharing other key characteristics—has declined.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Given that, FIN6 may have evolved as a whole to focus on these extortive intrusions.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: However, based on tactical differences between these ransomware incidents and historical FIN6 activity, it is also possible that some FIN6 operators have been carrying out ransomware deployment intrusions independently of the group’s payment card breaches.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Which of those scenarios is happening would influence how pressing a threat the group’s card data breach tactics continue to be.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Criminal operations and relationships are highly adaptable, so we commonly encounter such attribution challenges in regards to criminal activity.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

text: Given that these intrusions have been sustained for almost a year, we expect that continued research into further intrusion attempts may enable us to more fully answer these questions regarding FIN6’s current status.
source: Pick-Six_ Intercepting a FIN6 Intrusion, an Actor Recently Tied to Ryuk and LockerGoga Ransomware _ Mandiant.html

New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems

Posted by
Morphisec Labs on February 27, 2019

















Share











This post was authored by Michael Gorelik and Alon Groisman.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: Over the past 8-10 weeks, Morphisec has been tracking multiple sophisticated attacks targeting Point of Sale thin clients globally.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: More specifically, on the 6th of February we identified an extremely high number of prevention events stopping Cobalt Strike backdoor execution, with some of the attacks expressly targeting Point of Sale VMWare Horizon thin clients.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: Based on the initial indicators, we identified FrameworkPOS scraping malware installed on some of the thin clients, after initializing PowerShell/WMI stages that downloaded and reflectively loaded Cobalt-Strike beacon with PowerShell extension directly into the memory.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: We found many indicators linking specifically to the FIN6 group (WMI/PowerShell, FrameworkPOS, lateral movement and privilege escalation), with the difference of moving from Metasploit to Cobalt-Strike).
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: Some indicators are also tied to the EmpireMonkey group.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: At this point, we don’t have enough data for proper attribution.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: If successful, the Cobalt Strike beacon payload gives attackers full control over the infected system and the ability to move laterally to other systems, harvest user credentials, execute code and more, all while evading advanced EDR scanning techniques.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: Digging deeper into the notification and the telemetry, we identified victims across the United States, Japan and India from the finance, insurance and healthcare (diagnostic image processing) sectors, as well as additional targets globally.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: Following additional retro-hunting on Virus Total, we identified multiple servers that were, and still are, delivering the Cobalt Strike beacon using the same delivery pattern and same C2 communication pattern.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: We have notified the customers and the legal authorities about the currently active C2 servers.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: Morphisec Labs is currently still analyzing the infiltration methods (unknown); due to this we will present only partial technical information in this report.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: However, we believe it important to publish even a partial analysis so that enterprises are aware of, and immediately block, any access to the URLs listed below.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text:
Technical information:
Infiltration
As stated in the introduction, the infiltration vector is yet to be determined, although after retro-hunting on VT and matching it to our known telemetry events, we believe that at least one vector is executed through HTA files that execute PowerShell scripts as part of an embedded VBScript.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text:
Script stager
Additional hunting reveals additional scripts that lead to the same Cobalt Strike beacon.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: It is not known if the scripts below are part of a lateral movement or just additional examples of infiltration samples.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: However, at least some of them are executed through WMI which may indicate an intermediate stage.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text:
POWERSHELL


 
JAVASCRIPT

 
BAT


 
PowerShell Stager
All the various scripts are decoded to the following PowerShell pattern:

The script above decompresses an additional level of PowerShell stager (regular Gzip):

 

Clearly, the marked base64 encoded script represents the next stage shellcode that is either remotely injected into the existing 32 bit or into a newly created 32 bit PowerShell process (if the current PowerShell is 64bit).
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: Some samples differentiate in the way the VirtualAlloc and CreateThread are declared.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text:
Shellcode Stager
The injected shellcode is a regular Metasploit downloader shellcode that traverses the PEB, resolves the function names by the standard ROR 13 hash, and downloads the next stage shellcode directly into memory from the C2.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: The pattern of the C2 download request destination is generally URL:PORT/[a-zA-Z0-9]{4}.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: It executes InternetConnectA, InternetOpenA, HttpOpenRequestA, HttpSendRequestA for the purpose of downloading the next stage.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text:
Cobalt Strike Beacon
Morphisec observed 2 types of beacons during this campaign, the first one is a regular direct reflective loaded Cobalt Strike DLL beacon, usually XOR encoded.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: The second type is a shellcode backdoor beacon with PowerShell and Mimikatz functionality.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text:
Persistency and FrameworkPOS
In some cases, after executing the backdoors, the attackers install “WindowsHelpAssistant” task in the task scheduler.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: In turn, this, on login, uses rundll32.exe with System privileges to execute and export function “workerInstance” from a downloaded binary DLL “Assistant32.dll”.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: We also observed similar command execution as part of the HKLM Run key.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: The “Assistant32.dll” is the FrameworkPOS scraper that shares similar TTPs to a previously seen FrameworkPOS used by FIN6.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: The malware XOR’s (xor 0xAA)
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: the credit card information before exfiltration through DNS tunneling.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text:
Conclusions
These types of advanced attacks that utilize memory to evade detection solutions either by reflectively loading libraries, hollowing process memory or injecting code into new processes, are harder and harder to attribute due to the simple fact that more and more criminals are taking advantage of the strength of these evasion techniques and the weakness of runtime detection technologies to cope with such evasion.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: The attackers have the advantage of choosing where to execute their malicious code and when to execute it, while runtime detection solutions cannot constantly scan the memory to detect the attack precisely when it manifests without significantly impacting the performance of the process runtime.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: It is important to note that Morphisec prevents these types of attacks immediately, without any prior knowledge of the attack form or techniques.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

text: The forensic information used in this analysis was captured after the attack was already prevented.
source: New Global Cyber Attack on Point of Sale Systems.html

Cyber Crime
Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: We discovered that the online credit card skimming attack known as Magecart or E-Skimming was actively operating on 3,126 online shops.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
By: Joseph C Chen
		
			October 10, 2019
Read time: 6 min (1565 words)
	















Save to Folio






 Subscribe












Updated on October 14, 2019 at 2:50 AM PST to add a statement from Volusion.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: We discovered that the online credit card skimming attack known as Magecart or E-Skimming was actively operating on 3,126 online shops.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Our data shows that the attack started on September 7, 2019.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: All of the impacted online shops are hosted on the cloud platform of the e-commerce service provider “Volusion,” one of the top e-commerce platforms in the market.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: This is actually the third time we have identified a card skimmer injected into the cloud platform of an e-commerce provider.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Two other businesses were already victimized this year: a campus e-commerce platform and a hotel e-commerce platform.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: These targets are obviously appealing to cybercriminals since they are connected to multiple — in this most recent case, thousands of — online shops.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: We found malicious code injected into a JavaScript library provided by Volusion to their client shops.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The injected code loaded another JavaScript stored on a Google Storage service.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The loaded script is almost a direct copy of a normal JavaScript library but has a credit card skimmer carefully integrated.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: When customers submit their payment information, the skimmer will copy and send the personal information and credit card details to an exfiltration server belonging to the attackers.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Our team contacted Google and they have removed the file.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The attack is currently offline.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: As of publication, Volusion has acknowledged and fixed the issue.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Figure 1.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
Online credit card skimming attack chain

Figure 2.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Country distribution of online shop users who accessed the card skimmer (based on data from the Trend Micro™ Smart Protection Network™ infrastructure)
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: During our investigation, we found that the attackers seemed more experienced and thoughtful than many other skimmer groups.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: They did not simply add their malicious code at the top or end of a script; instead, they carefully integrated the code into the original script to be part of the execution flow of the program.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The code was also written as simply as possible, making it difficult to be identified in a big library.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Furthermore, they registered the domain of their exfiltration server in a similar style to a legitimate Volusion domain.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Considering the modus operandi, we believe the attackers are from Magecart Group 6, which has also been identified as the notorious threat actor FIN6.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: We found similarities in the code used in this attack and the code used in FIN6’s previous attacks on British Airways and Newegg.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
Analysis of the code injection
The attackers injected their code into a library provided on Volusion’s e-commerce platform for their client shops.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The script, described by the comments on the library, includes the necessary code for the pop-out feature of the shop’s navigation menu.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: It was also used on the shop checkout page.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
The script is located at:

hxxps://[online shop domain]/a/j/vnav.js

The attackers didn’t just inject their code inside the library.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: They also integrated their code into the original function of jQueryUI code to be executed with the original execution flow.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: They created a new object “e.widget.unbridge” right before the original object “e.widget.bridge” and the malicious code is inside the new object.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: It’s worth noting that the attackers even wrote their malicious code in a similar coding style to make it look more like a part of the original source code.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The injected object will create a new script element to load another remote script stored on Google Storage.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Figure 3.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
Malicious script injected into Volusion’s JavaScript library

Figure 4.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
Comparison of the original Volusion script (left) and the script with injection (right); the injected malicious code is highlighted
Analysis of the credit card skimmer
The loaded remote script is on Google Storage: 

hxxps[:]//storage[.]googleapis[.]com/volusionapi/resources.js

Much of the code inside the script is from the library “js-cookie” version 2.2.1.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: However, the attackers modified it and integrated a credit card skimmer into the original script.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The skimmer binds at the events “mousedown” and “touchstart” of the payment submit button.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: This means that when victims click (from desktop) or touch (from mobile devices) the submit button, the events will be triggered and the skimmer will be executed.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Figure 5.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Comparison of the JavaScript library injected with the skimmer (left) and the original “js-cookie” library (right)
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The skimmer copies the information on the entire payment form: the victim’s name, address, phone number, email address, and credit card details (the number, cardholder name, expiration month, expiration year, and CVV number).
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Once the skimmer has the credit card details, it serializes the copied data into a string and encodes it with Base64.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Then, it performs a character permutation on the encoded string to make sure it can’t be directly decoded with Base64 decoding.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The data will then be stored in sessionStorage with the key “__utmz_opt_in_out”.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
The next time the skimmer is loaded (usually on the page after the payment), it will detect if there is data inside sessionStorage and it will use HTTP POST to send the stolen payment information to a remote server at “hxxps[:]//volusion-cdn[.]com/analytics/beacon” for exfiltration.

Figure 6.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
Main script of the credit card skimmer
Note that the attackers used the domain “volusion-cdn[.]com” for their exfiltration server, a similar name to Volusion’s legitimate server.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: A possible reason why the attackers stored the skimmer on Google Storage is because Volusion is also running its service on the Google Cloud Platform.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
Evidence of Magecart or FIN6
As previously mentioned, based on the modus operandi, we believe the attackers are from Magecart Group 6, also known as the threat actor FIN6.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
Here are the connections we considered:

Group 6 is known to only target top-tier victims, investing in scams where they can receive a big payoff from one attack.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: This single hack of Volusion allows them to receive credit card data from 3,126 online shops.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: From the previous skimming attack on the British Airways and Newegg websites, we know that Group 6 tried to register the domains of the exfiltration server to be similar to the victims’ domains.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: In this case, the domain of the exfiltration server is “volusion-cdn[.]com” — very similar to the valid domain “cdn3[.]volusion[.]com” from Volusion.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: In addition, the exfiltration domains used during the British Airways, Newegg, and Volusion attacks are all registered through Namecheap.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: We found that the skimmer is an improved version of the previous skimmer used in the attacks on British Airways and Newegg.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Both old and current skimmers are written with jQuery, serialize the stolen data, and use the jQuery.ajax function to POST data to a remote server.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Although the older skimmer is much simpler compared to the current one, it didn’t encode the stolen data or store the data in sessionStorage before the exfiltration.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: It’s also interesting to see that the skimmer in this attack binds to event “mousedown” and event “touchstart” of the payment submit button.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: The previous Group 6 skimmer binds to event “mouseup” and event “touchend”.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: These events are different, but they are the pairs of each other that trigger the skimmer at almost the same time.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: It seems that they want to trigger the skimmer at the same moment, but the current version binds on two opposite events of the pairs to avoid detection from heuristic rules.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: touchstart', z)
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: It seems that Magecart is continuing to change and experiment with new attack methods, refining its skimmer to evade detection.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Sophisticated groups such as these will always try to find new ways to stay undetected in their victims’ systems.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: To defend against this type of threat, website owners should regularly check and strengthen their security with patches and server segregation.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Site owners should also employ robust authentication mechanisms, especially for those that store and manage sensitive data.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: IT and security teams should restrict or disable outdated components and habitually monitor websites and applications for any indicators of suspicious activity that could lead to data exfiltration, execution of unknown scripts, or unauthorized access and modification.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:
A Volusion spokesperson has added the following statement:
"Volusion was alerted of a data security incident and can confirm that it was resolved within a few hours of notification.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: We are coordinating with authorities on this matter, and continue to enhance our systems that detect and prevent unauthorized access to user accounts.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: A limited portion of customer information was compromised from a subset of our merchants.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: This included credit card information, but not other associated personally identifying details.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: We are not aware of any fraudulent activity connected to this matter.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text: Volusion has taken action to help secure accounts, and we are continuing to monitor this matter in order to assure the security of our merchants.
source: Magecart Card Skimmers Injected Into Online Shops.html

text:

text:

text:

text:
FireEye Threat Intelligence and iSIGHT Partners recently combined
our research to illuminate the activities of one particular threat group:
FIN6.

text:

visibility into FIN6’s operations, from initial intrusion to the methods
used to navigate the victims’ networks to the sale of the stolen
payment card data in an underground marketplace.

text:
Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again 








 





Light
Dark






August 29, 2019
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
By Ole Villadsen



Kevin Henson

Melissa Frydrych

Joey Victorino


  14 min read




Advanced Threats
Incident Response
Malware
Threat Intelligence














 

IBM X-Force Incident Response and Intelligence Services (IRIS) responds to security incidents across the globe.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: During a recent incident response investigation, our team identified new attacks by the financially motivated attack group ITG08, also known as FIN6.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: ITG08 is an organized cybercrime gang that has been active since 2015, mostly targeting point-of-sale (POS) machines in brick-and-mortar retailers and companies in the hospitality sector in the U.S. and Europe.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: More recently, the group has been observed targeting e-commerce environments by injecting malicious code into online checkout pages of compromised websites — a technique known as online skimming — thereby stealing payment card data transmitted to the vendor by unsuspecting customers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Based on our investigation and analysis of its adversarial tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs), we believe ITG08 is actively attacking multinational organizations, targeting specific employees with spear phishing emails advertising fake job advertisements and repeatedly deploying the More_eggs JScript backdoor malware (aka Terra Loader, SpicyOmelette).
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: This tool, a TTP observed in ITG08 attacks since 2018, is sold on the dark web by an underground malware-as-a-service (MaaS) provider.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Attackers use it to create, expand and cement their foothold in compromised environments.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Past campaigns by ITG08 using the More_eggs backdoor were last reported in February 2019.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In the campaign we investigated, the attackers employed additional TTPs historically associated with ITG08, including the use of Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to automate the remote execution of PowerShell scripts, PowerShell commands with base64 encoding, and Metasploit and PowerShell to move laterally and deploy malware.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Lastly, the attackers used Comodo code-signing certificates several times during the course of the campaign.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Many of the above TTPs are not unique to ITG08, but collectively, and with the use of More_eggs, strengthen the link to this group.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Let’s take a closer look at ITG08’s TTPs that are relevant to the campaign we investigated, starting with its spear phishing and intrusion tactics and covering information on its use of the More_eggs backdoor.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Please note that Visa has attributed the use of this backdoor to FIN6 in attacks that took place in 2018.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Further linking the activity with the same threat actor, several of the network indicators and TTPs we encountered in this case — including the use of fake job advertisements as a lure in spear phishing — overlap with those reported earlier in 2019 by both Visa and Proofpoint researchers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Analysis of the Intrusion
ITG08’s TTPs in compromising targeted organizations follow the typical framework for APT attacks.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The following sections go over the steps taken by the attackers to gain an initial foothold and persist on the victimized organization’s networks.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Initial Compromise
To gain access to victim environments, the threat actor began by targeting handpicked employees using LinkedIn messaging and email, advertising fake jobs to lure recipients into checking into the supposed offers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In one case, we uncovered evidence indicating that the attacker had established communication with a victim via email and convinced them to click on a Google Drive URL purporting to contain an attractive job advert.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Once clicked, the URL displayed the message, “Online preview is not available,” then presented a second URL leading to a compromised or rogue domain, where the victim could download the payload under the guise of a job description:

Figure 1: Link provided in spear phishing email to an employee
That URL, in turn, downloaded a ZIP file containing a malicious Windows Script File (WSF) that initiated the infection routine of the More_eggs backdoor:

Figure 2: Final landing page that downloads a malicious file
Based on file system artifacts examined during our investigation, the ZIP file and WSF files were deleted upon a successful malware infection, likely in an attempt to prevent researchers from recovering the original files from the filesystem.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The filesystem, however, contained evidence of a nonmalicious decoy document dropped to the disk drive during the spear phishing attacks.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Gaining a Foothold
The spear phishing attacks unfortunately led to initial compromise and the installation of the More_eggs JScript backdoor, which established a reverse shell connection to the attacker’s command-and-control (C&C) infrastructure.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Additional capabilities of the More_eggs malware include the download and execution of files and scripts and running commands using cmd.exe.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: X-Force IRIS determined that the More_eggs backdoor later downloaded additional files, including a signed binary shellcode loader and a signed Dynamic Link Library (DLL), as described below, to create a reverse shell and connect to a remote host.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The shellcode loader was observed on one infected device as updater.exe with the Metasploit-style service name APTYnDS1ABEuUHEA, indicating that it was installed as a service.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Reconnaissance, Lateral Movement and Privilege Escalation
Once the attackers established a foothold on the network, they employed WMI and PowerShell techniques to perform network reconnaissance and move laterally within the environment.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: This type of method, called living off the land, can often blend with legitimate system administration activities, which can make it challenging for security controls to detect.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The attackers used this technique to remotely install a Metasploit reverse TCP stager on select systems, subsequently spawning a Meterpreter session and Mimikatz.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Meterpreter is a payload component in the Metasploit Framework that uses in-memory DLL injection, which can lead to a compromise by malware or any malicious code/commands.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Mimikatz is a post-exploitation tool that allows attackers to extract credentials from volatile memory.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Stolen credentials are usually leveraged to facilitate privilege escalation and further lateral movement through the compromised environment.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Once the Metasploit reverse TCP stager executed, it downloaded and loaded a second stage Meterpreter DLL into memory, allowing the attacker to spawn a Meterpreter session via a handler and initiate the loading of extensions, such as Mimikatz.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In addition to the More_eggs malware, the attacker leveraged in-memory attacks by injecting malicious code, in this case Mimikatz, into legitimate system processes.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Establishing Persistence
To cement their foothold and add persistence throughout the compromised environment, X-Force IRIS uncovered evidence that the attacker had selected several additional devices on which to install the More_eggs backdoor, creating redundancy in ways to get back into the network.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: ITG08 remotely connected to these devices using PowerShell and WMI and downloaded and executed a DLL file, subsequently installing More_eggs on the device without dropping the nonmalicious decoy document.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
More_eggs: Malware Analysis
ITG08 Leveraging a Malware-as-a-Service Provider
A recently rising attack tool in ITG08 campaigns has been the More_eggs JScript backdoor.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: But while it was recently identified with ITG08 activity, the More_eggs backdoor is apparently developed and sold through an underground MaaS provider.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: This vendor not only supplies the backdoor malware, but also offers related technical services, such as preparing the network infrastructure to download More_eggs-related files and furnishing resources for C&C purposes.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In addition to More_eggs, the same underground vendor is also responsible for producing the signed DLL described below, which creates a reverse shell (ReverseShell Executable).
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
We based this assessment on code similarities between the DLL and other samples created by the same vendor, including the DLL that drops the More_eggs backdoor.

Figure 3:
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Network indicators revealing the use of an underground MaaS vendor selling More_eggs and malicious infrastructure services
The More_eggs Dropper DLL
After a successful phishing attack in which users have opened emails and browsed to malicious links, ITG08 attackers install the More_eggs JScript backdoor on user devices alongside several other malware components.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The process begins with the consistent execution of a malicious DLL using the legitimate regsvr32.exe Windows Utility.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Once executed, the DLL is deleted from the system and its components are dropped to the system.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Before being deleted, the DLL executes a string decoding routine that is designed to execute for about a minute, spiking central processing unit (CPU) usage for the regsvr32.exe process.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Once the strings are decoded, the More_eggs components are decrypted, dropped to the system
(normally in the %APPDATA%\Microsoft\ or %ProgramData%\Microsoft\ directories) and executed.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Analyzing the More_eggs JScript Backdoor
The analysis in this section details the functionality of More_eggs backdoor samples specific to this investigation, so please bear in mind that the same malware can be deployed differently in other campaigns and by alternate attackers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The core functionality of the samples analyzed in this campaign remained the same as described by previous researchers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: We aimed to add additional detail about the inner workings of the malware, including its C&C communications flow, its filesystem activity, and some encryption and encoding schemes used by the samples we analyzed.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The More_eggs backdoor is executed entirely in memory, never touching the filesystem in an unencrypted state.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Notable configuration data is hardcoded and includes its C&C server address, malware version number and an Rkey value, which is believed to identify campaign perpetrators to the vendor:
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The Rkey value is appended with a two-byte, pseudorandomly generated string used to construct an RC4 key.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The Rkey variable is part of the ciphering key used to encrypt C&C communications.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The RC4 key is then used to encrypt data, which is additionally basE91 encoded and sent back to the C&C. BasE91 is a method for encoding binary as ASCII characters.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Upon initial execution, the backdoor checks its environment to determine whether it is running with administrative or user privileges, and if proper components are present on the system.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: To check the user’s privilege level on the newly infected device, it attempts to read the registry key HKEY_USERS\S-1-5-19\Environment\TEMP; a successful read means it is running with administrative privileges, and the backdoor builds the path %ProgramData%\Microsoft.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: If it is not running with administrative privileges, the path %AppData%\Microsoft is used.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The More_eggs backdoor obtains the username and computer name of the infected device, and if running with privileges, it reads the following registry key: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\Notepad\<computername>.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: If not running with privileges, it reads the key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Notepad\<username> instead.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The data in these Windows registry keys is expected to be a comma-separated list of files with no extension.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The .txt extension is appended to the name by the backdoor.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: If these files exist along with msxsl.exe in the proper location, either %ProgramData%\Microsoft or %AppData%\Microsoft, the malware’s execution continues.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Once the environment is checked, the backdoor will check for network connectivity by sending an HTTP GET request to hxxp://www.w3[.]org/1999/XSL/Format, ensuring the response is “This is another XSL namespace\n.”
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html
