Meterpreter Reverse TCP Stagers
Beyond using More_eggs as a backdoor, the attackers in this campaign also used offensive security tools and PowerShell scripts to carry out the different stages of the attack.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The PowerShell scripts analyzed during our investigation contained Metasploit Reverse TCP stagers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: These stagers were used to execute shellcode that connected back to an attacker’s server and injected Meterpreter components, such as Mimikatz, into the memory space of legitimate processes.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: After injecting Meterpreter into memory, the attacker had complete control of the infected device.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
The reverse TCP PowerShell stagers functioned as follows:

The reverse TCP PowerShell stagers were obfuscated with base64 encoding and GZip compression.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: This encoding scheme is standard for Meterpreter PowerShell stagers.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The original command contained a base64-encoded loader script.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The loader script base64 decodes, Gzip decompresses and executes a Metasploit PowerShell reflection payload in memory.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The reflection payload base64 decodes a Meterpreter reverse TCP shellcode, injects it into memory using .NET reflection methods and executes the decoded shellcode.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The shellcode connects back to the attacker’s server.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Meterpreter components, such as the core module and metsvr.dll, and extensions, such as Mimikatz, are injected into the memory space of a legitimate process.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Figure 14: Original command

Figure 15: Decoded loader

Figure 16: Decoded reflection payload
Metasploit Shellcode Loader
As our analysis continued, X-Force IRIS found a UPX-packed Metasploit shellcode loader (49340.txt) during the forensic investigation of compromised devices.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: This loader attempted to masquerade as the Apache Bench application and notably contained metadata and project paths (.PDB), indicating that it may be attempting to masquerade as other applications as well, a rather typical behavior for malicious binaries.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The shellcode was loaded into memory and designed to receive an RC4-encrypted buffer, which was decrypted and executed in memory.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The sample also contained a Comodo code-signing certificate issued to “MAHTEM LTD,” which we believe is one of a number of fake companies established to purchase the certificates.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The sample we analyzed further contained five binary entries in a resource named “REGISTRY” — 35, 224, 409, 3908 and 4994 — each containing some obfuscated shellcode.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Once loaded into memory, the shellcode connected back to a remote host, receiving 4 bytes in return.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Those were XORed with the string 0xad350bdd and had 0x100 added to it.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: This value was then used as the size specification for the next received buffer, which was RC4-decrypted with the resulting 16-byte key and executed in memory.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
A ReverseShell Executable
Yet another tool in the attackers’ arsenal for this campaign was a DLL backdoor executable that X-Force IRIS found during the investigation.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: When executed via its DllRegisterServer export function, the DLL connected to a remote host on port 443 and created a reverse shell.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
In this investigation, the DLL connected to 185[.]204[.]2[.]182 and contained a Comodo code-signing certificate issued to “D Bacte Ltd.”
ITG08 Attacks Organizations for Financial Gain
ITG08 has been around for over four years now.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Its attacks are financially motivated, sophisticated and persistent.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The group historically has specialized in stealing payment card data from POS machines and has more recently expanded operations to target card-not-present data from online transactions.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: To follow information about ITG08 as it emerges, please join us on X-Force Exchange.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Mitigation Tips
Effective network defense and threat intelligence rely on multiple factors, such as knowing the network’s attack surface, understanding the threat actor’s motivations and TTPs, and the skill and knowledge of the security team that enable it to identify malicious behavior.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: IBM X-Force IRIS has gained insight into ITG08’s intrusion methods, ability to navigate laterally, use of custom and open-source tools, and typical persistence mechanisms.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Our team has provided the following mitigation tips for defenders who are looking out for attacks by this group.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Educate Users About Email
X-Force IRIS determined that the ITG08 compromise was the result of a phishing email in which the initial compromise was made possible by a victim who clicked on a malicious attachment.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Role-based security awareness training should be at the top of the list of any organization’s mitigation strategies to help employees recognize phishing emails and possible malicious attachments, and to educate them about their security responsibilities with regards to reporting potentially malicious emails.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Search for Known IoCs
After the phishing email resulted in a successful infiltration, ITG08 used the More_eggs backdoor to gain a foothold and infect additional devices.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: More_eggs-related artifacts such as the DLL dropper have extremely low antivirus (AV) detection rates, based on analysis conducted via VirusTotal (VT).
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: For example, a More_eggs DLL dropper submitted to VT on April 18, 2019 had a detection rate of only 5 percent.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: To detect this malware, critical events should be analyzed based on the attacker’s patterns.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: SYSMON or an endpoint detection and response tool should be configured to detect the combined use of msxsl.exe and WMI.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In addition, Registry keys and scheduled tasks should be analyzed for indications of persistence.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: The network should also be scrutinized for any privilege escalation events and any signs of internal reconnaissance.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: YARA signatures should also be created to assist security personnel in detecting the More_eggs malware.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: YARA signatures for X-Force IRIS premium subscribers can be provided on request.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Analyze Logs
Other mitigation strategies against this type of activity include analyzing host-based firewall logs for internal pivoting, unauthorized listening executables and scanning activity.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: In addition, configuring PowerShell script logging and identifying any obfuscation will assist in mitigating ITG08’s use of PowerShell to conduct malicious activity.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: ITG08 has also demonstrated the use of stolen credentials; therefore, multiple failed login attempts and/or unauthorized account usage may be indicators of ITG08 activity on a network.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Monitor for Remote Services
X-Force IRIS also recommends taking steps to prevent lateral movement.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Although lateral movement can be difficult to detect, a spike in usage of Windows tools, such as remote administration services (PowerShell Remoting and WMI), should be monitored.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Detection and monitoring capabilities should be in place and network defenders should be familiar with what is considered a “normal” baseline on their user network.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Without a baseline of “normal” activity, the use of Windows tools may blend in with legitimate activity, which can allow attackers to continue to live off the land unnoticed.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Rethink Network Architecture
Security defenders should examine network architecture to see how the network is segregated, what Windows tools are restricted or used by administrators, and what alerts are set up to warrant personnel review.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Least privilege principals should be implemented for all users on the network, and a strong password management system with two-factor authentication and password expiration dates should be deployed as an additional layer of security.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Pen Test!
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Organizations looking to limit the ways by which attackers can infiltrate their networks should be mindful of ongoing patching of vulnerabilities.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: After reaching maturity on the vulnerability assessment front, mitigation strategies should also include penetration testing to find unknown vulnerabilities related to people, software and hardware used on the organization’s critical assets and externally facing resources.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text:
Incident Response
Nowadays, no organization can be exempt from planning and drilling incident response plans in the face of potential security incidents.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: Conducting tabletop exercises and regularly drilling plans can help organizations proactively prepare and take control of an incident if ever one should occur.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: For additional resources and information, please check out X-Force IRIS.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

text: If you believe your organization may be under attack, please call the X-Force Emergency Response Hotline at 888-241-9812.
source: More_eggs, Anyone_ Threat Actor ITG08 Strikes Again.html

ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework 








 





Light
Dark






April 7, 2020
By Ole Villadsen

  6 min read




Advanced Threats
Threat Intelligence
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The past two years have borne witness to the increasing collaboration between organized cybercrime groups to avoid duplication of efforts and maximize profits.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Although this collaboration has primarily occurred between gangs developing and distributing well-known banking Trojans, such as Emotet, TrickBot and IcedID, it does not stop there.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: In a new and dangerous twist to this trend, IBM X-Force Incident Response and Intelligence Services (IRIS) research believes that the elite cybercriminal threat actor ITG08, also known as FIN6, has partnered with the malware gang behind one of the most active Trojans — TrickBot — to use TrickBot’s new malware framework dubbed “Anchor” against organizations for financial profit.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The Anchor malware framework itself is not new and its origins date back to at least 2018.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: It appears to be tightly connected to TrickBot and is likely programmed by the same malware authors that work on TrickBot.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Cybersecurity firms SentinelOne and Cybereason have published reports in recent months describing Anchor as new malware developed by the TrickBot gang for use in targeted attacks against enterprises, including a new PowerShell-based backdoor called PowerTrick.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text:
ITG08 and TrickBot — A Loaded Duo
ITG08/FIN6 is an organized cybercrime gang that has been active since 2015, primarily targeting point-of-sale (POS) machines in brick-and-mortar retailers and companies in the hospitality sector across the U.S. and Europe.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: TrickBot is a banking Trojan that emerged in 2016 and has since grown to be one of the top, and most sophisticated, Trojans being used by organized cybercrime gangs believed to be hailing out of Russia.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: In the past six months, the Anchor backdoor malware, which includes a variant that communicates over DNS (Anchor_DNS), has been used in targeted attacks on enterprise networks — including POS systems — following initial infection by the TrickBot Trojan.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The way organizations are being attacked ties with typical ITG08 activity reported throughout the past few years.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Through connecting our own findings with information from other security research reports, X-Force IRIS has determined that the threat actor ITG08 has partnered with the TrickBot gang to use that group’s PowerTrick and Anchor backdoor malware for attacks on high-profile targets.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: This post provides more detail on that connection.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text:
Tying ITG08 (FIN6) With Use of TrickBot’s Anchor Framework
A past analysis by X-Force IRIS gave extensive information about ITG08’s use of a backdoor known as “More_eggs”.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The gang’s relationship with the boutique underground provider selling the TerraLoader loader and More_eggs backdoor leads to direct evidence of its use of PowerTrick and Anchor.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Bringing this cybercrime seller back into the picture, SentinelOne researchers reported observing a threat actor using PowerTrick and Anchor to download two samples developed and sold by the same seller: a TerraLoader that installs the More_eggs backdoor and a TerraLoader that deploys a signed Metasploit shellcode loader.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text:
The evidence provided below links these two samples to ITG08.
More_eggs Sample Analysis
X-Force IRIS is almost certain the TerraLoader and More_eggs samples were purchased by ITG08 based on similarities with two other More_eggs samples.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: We encountered the first sample in 2019 during an investigation of attacks we attributed to ITG08.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: We found the second sample, a Terraloader dropping a More_eggs backdoor, in a public repository that also showed ties to the ITG08 group.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text:

Table 1: Comparison of three More_eggs samples and their command-and-control (C&C) domains

All three C&C domains were created at the same time using the same email registration address.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Two of the samples — the one downloaded by Anchor and the one attributed to ITG08 — use the same RKey, which is used in part to encrypt communications with the C&C host.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Two of the TerraLoaders were compiled within two weeks of each other.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The remaining TerraLoader could not be recovered.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The RKey in the final sample, “wearenotcobaltthanks,” is a reference to the Cobalt Gang group, which previously had used the More_eggs backdoor.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: X-Force IRIS has found a similar message in other More_eggs samples attributed to ITG08: a variable called “Researchers” with the content, “We are not cobalt gang, stop associating us with such skids!”
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text:
Metasploit Shellcode Loader Sample Analysis
SentinelOne previously observed Anchor downloading a signed TerraLoader.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: That first step was followed by installing an Apache Bench executable hollowed out with a Metasploit loader shellcode that received an RC4 encrypted payload.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: X-Force IRIS lacks the sample hash or code-signing certificate to attribute this malware definitively to ITG08, but it is very similar to other samples we did attribute to the ITG08 group.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: In 2019, X-Force IRIS observed ITG08 employ a signed Metasploit shellcode loader masquerading as the Apache Bench application and containing a Comodo code-signing certificate issued to “MAHTEM LTD.”
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The shellcode was loaded into memory and designed to receive an RC4-encrypted buffer.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: This sample was used during an intrusion that featured the use of More_eggs.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: X-Force IRIS identified a signed TerraLoader in a public repository that also decrypts a shellcode loader masquerading as Apache Bench.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The sample used a code-signing certificate issued to “D. Bacte Ltd.”, which we found in other samples that we attributed to ITG08 in some of our previous investigations.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text:
More Evidence of ITG08’s (FIN6) Fingerprints on TrickBot Malware
Further clues connect ITG08 to TrickBot and its operators’ other malware.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text:
Generally speaking, the tactics used to deploy More_eggs in victim environments, as well as other threat actor tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs) used during these Anchor campaigns, are unusually consistent with those used by ITG08.
More_eggs & TerraLoader Deployment
According to SentinelOne, the threat actor used PowerShell to download and execute a TerraLoader that installed More_eggs.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: X-Force IRIS has observed ITG08 employ the same tactic whereby it used PowerShell and Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) to download and execute TerraLoader, then install More_eggs on remote hosts.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: X-Force IRIS has not observed any other actors who use More_eggs employ this tactic.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Those who do typically install More_eggs only during the initial infection, after which they download additional malware or tools to proceed with their intrusion phase.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: TTPs Consistent With ITG08
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: In a blog about the subject, researchers from Cybereason noted that many of the threat actor TTPs they observed while using the Anchor framework were consistent with FIN6 activity, including the targeting of POS systems and the use of tools such as Metasploit, Cobalt Strike and AdFind.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: X-Force IRIS has also encountered these TTPs in attacks that we attributed to ITG08.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: While these TTPs alone are insufficient to attribute the activity to ITG08, they are nevertheless fully consistent with ITG08 activity.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: On a final note, X-Force IRIS is unaware of other threat actors deploying the combination of TerraLoader, More_eggs and Metasploit shellcode loaders in the manner described above.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: This activity, combined with the additional TTPs attributed to ITG08, such as the use of Metasploit, Cobalt Strike and AdFind while targeting POS systems, leads us to conclude with confidence that ITG08 is one of the threat actors using TrickBot’s PowerTrick and the Anchor malware framework.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text:
ITG08 Connecting to Evolve
ITG08’s partnership with the TrickBot gang to use its Anchor malware framework is the latest example of a cybercriminal group that has repeatedly demonstrated its ability to adopt new malware and adapt to changing circumstances that threaten the group’s ability to obtain illicit proceeds.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: In this respect, ITG08 behaves much like a commercial enterprise: adopting new technology, building strategic partnerships and grappling with changing markets by moving into new “lines of business” while leveraging their core strengths and outsourcing those of other groups.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: ITG08’s partnership with the TrickBot gang not only provides the group with new malware and potential access to enterprises infected with the TrickBot Trojan; it also reveals additional evidence of the group’s strategy to partner with other threat actors and malware developers.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: These varied relationships with elite cybercriminal actors and those who sell them tools, access and software allow ITG08 to continue to rely on its strengths in post-exploitation tactics, such as lateral movement, privilege escalation and data exfiltration, and outsource other attack vectors as needed.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: The partnership with TrickBot is not the only evolution for ITG08.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: In recent years, this group has evolved to employ additional means to obtain illicit proceeds, including the targeting of e-commerce environments by injecting malicious code into online checkout pages of compromised websites in a modus operandi known as “Magecart.”
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: ITG08 also maintains established relationships with underground malware suppliers, such as the one responsible for developing and selling the TerraLoader loader and More_eggs JScript backdoor.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: ITG08 continues to benefit from its relationship with the developer behind More_eggs, whose malware features very low antivirus detection rates and makes use of other methods to evade detection, such as bypassing application whitelisting.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: ITG08 has also been targeting e-commerce environments with a technique known as online skimming or grouped under what’s known as Magecart activity.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: In fact, ITG08 is the same group as Magecart Group 6.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: This relatively new activity almost certainly is a response to the adoption of EMV chips and point-to-point encryption.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: ITG08 may also be part of attacks that deploy ransomware, such as Ryuk, LockerGoga and MegaCortex, again in likely partnership with banking Trojan botnets, which could be a further attempt to move into new “markets” that do not rely on the need to monetize credit card data.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

text: Financially motivated, adaptable, sophisticated and persistent, ITG08 is likely to remain one of the most potent cybercriminal groups in this new decade.
source: ITG08 (aka FIN6) Partners With TrickBot Gang, Uses Anchor Framework.html

              FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware
             Threat Actors
                    April 09, 2019  Cyware Hacker News              The group was observed to deploy ransomware such as Ryuk and LockerGoga on compromised networks that did not contain any payment data.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: Just like its PoS exploits, FIN6 relied on Windows’
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) to move laterally across affected networks.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: FIN6, which is one of the sophisticated cybercriminal groups, has now moved to deploy ransomware in its attacks.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: This recent development was uncovered by security firm FireEye when it analyzed a cyber attack performed on an engineering industry.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: It was found that FIN6 installed ransomware on systems that did not have any payment data on them.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: The big pictureIn the attack analyzed by FireEye, FIN6 employed two different techniques after using Windows’ RDP to laterally move across the networks.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: This movement enabled FIN6 to then inject LockerGoga and Ryuk ransomware.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: The first technique involved executing an encoded command through PowerShell.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: The command downloaded a Cobalt Strike payload, which in turn was configured to drop a malicious payload onto the systems.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: This payload remains unknown as of now.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: The second technique involved the use of a Windows Service created by Metasploit, that was used to communicate with a C2 server for dropping additional payloads into compromised systems.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: This would allow FIN6 to escalate privileges in the system.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: Worth notingFireEye suggested that the group’s shift to ransomware might be the next method in its extortion related operations.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: “As the frequency of these intrusions deploying ransomware has increased, the cadence of activity traditionally attributed to FIN6—intrusions targeting point-of-sale (POS) environments, deploying TRINITY malware and sharing other key characteristics—has declined.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: Given that, FIN6 may have evolved as a whole to focus on these extortive intrusions,” the researchers stated in their blog.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text: As always, advanced cybercriminal groups like FIN6 are continuously evolving to evade security measures and subvert large-scale networks for monetary purposes.
source: FIN6 group goes from compromising PoS systems to deploying ransomware _ Cyware Alerts - Hacker News.html

text:
Visa Public
Visa Payment Fraud Disruption
-
Situational Intelligence Report
February 2019
FIN6 Cybercrime Group Expands Threat to eCommerce
Merchants
Summary
FIN6 is a financially motivated threat actor group in operation since at least 2015.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The group has
compromised multiple point-of-sale (POS) environments using the TRINITY POS (aka FrameworkPOS)
malware.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
In September 2017, forensic investigations of several undisclosed entities revealed evidence that
FIN6 actors changed to target card-not-present (CNP) data when they could not deploy their malware in
the POS environment.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Evidence shows that FIN6 injected malicious code into the merchants’ eCommerce
environment, placing skimming malware on the victims’ checkout pages.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Based on Visa Payment Fraud
Disruption’s (PFD) analysis of eCommerce compromises throughout 2018, FIN6’s focus on the CNP
environment has only amplified, suggesting that the cybercrime group has fully incorporated
targeting CNP environments into their criminal methodology.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The majority of eCommerce compromises reported in 2018 involved direct targeting of vulnerabilities
within the eCommerce website itself.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
As one of the more sophisticated groups targeting eCommerce
merchants, FIN6 brings their POS compromise approach to the emerging threat landscape of CNP
breaches.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
FIN6 targets companies, using phishing emails in an attempt to infect the targeted victim’s
network.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text: The actors then move through the network to identify POS and eCommerce environments.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
PFD
assesses that the increased focus of a sophisticated cybercrime group, such as FIN6, on eCommerce
environments is a broader representation of the overall cybercriminal focus on the CNP space.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Recent Activities
At the end of 2018, Visa Payment Intelligence analysts discovered that FIN6 actors targeted multiple high
value eCommerce merchants with malicious documents that contained links to a malicious server that
allowed the execution of PowerShell scripts, granting the attackers direct access to the merchants’
networks.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The PowerShell scripts were only present in memory, and did not download additional files to
the user’s machine, making it difficult for the victim to detect.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The FIN6 actors were able to utilize this
access to move through the merchant’s networks to access the eCommerce environment, and specifically
the payment servers.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
A full investigation of these compromises show that the FIN6 actors specifically
targeted the eCommerce networks and did not exploit them opportunistically.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf
fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Visa Public February 2019Visa Public
Visa Payment Fraud Disruption
Figure 1 - FIN6 eCommerce Attack Flow
Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures (TTPs)
Initial Compromise
FIN6 employs a multitude of tactics within the initial phase of their operations.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
In the most recent
compromises attributed to FIN6, forensic investigators identified the use of malicious documents to infect
victims with malware known as More_Eggs (aka Terra Loader) that is used to launch malicious scripts on
the infected machine.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Maintain Access
FIN6 establishes a foothold within a victim’s environment by leveraging various payloads, such as
components of the Metasploit Framework (e.g., Meterpreter, JSPSPY and CmdSQL), or through a
PFD-18-024 Visa Public February 2019Visa Public
Visa Payment Fraud Disruption
specialized version of the AMMYY remote administration tool (RAT) known as FlawedAmmyy.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
In the most
recent cases, attackers then establish persistent access to the victim’s network using Meterpreter related
code, allowing the attackers to maintain a remote connection to the infected system.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Internal Reconnaissance
FIN6 uses legitimate publicly available tools to map the internal network and conduct reconnaissance.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
During the reconnaissance phase, the actors gather information on systems running SQL Database Server
instances and dump schemas for multiple databases and SQL user accounts.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The actors also target
network credentials using a malware family known as Stealer One (see below in the section Technical
Analysis and Indicators of Compromise).
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Additionally, FIN6 employs legitimate administrative tools, such as:
• Microsoft's built-in SQL querying tool (osql.exe)
• Query Express (a free, portable graphical SQL client)
•
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
AdFind (a free command-line tool for querying Active Directory)
•
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
ProcDump (a Microsoft SysInternals command-line utility used to perform analysis of running
processes).
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Escalate Privileges
Once FIN6’s accesses are established with preferred backdoors, they use additional public utilities, such as
Windows Credentials Editor and Metasploit-related tools, for privilege escalation and credential harvesting.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Move Laterally/Maintain Presence
Capitalizing on data acquired via internal reconnaissance, FIN6 relies on credentials stolen from various
systems (e.g. usernames and password hashes) for lateral movement.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Investigations show that FIN6 relies
on PowerShell scripts and Meterpreter based shells to maintain access to and move laterally through the
network (see below in the section Technical Analysis and Indicators of Compromise).
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf
fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Visa Public February 2019Visa Public
Visa Payment Fraud Disruption
Technical Analysis and Indicators of Compromise (IOCs)
Malicious Files – Stealer One
Stealer One is a credential stealer, first observed by industry forensic investigators in March 2017.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The
malware targets a variety of applications, including email clients, web browsers, FTP clients, and other file
transfer utilities.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

More_Eggs Network IOCs
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
In addition to the C2 information provided, which can change, below are some network IOCs that can be
used to detect More_Eggs beaconing out of the network:
Connectivity Check
0B
The malware checks network connectivity by sending an HTTP HEAD (GET in some new
versions) request to the following legitimate URL:
• hxxp://www[.]w3[.]org/1999/XSL/Format
Sleep Function
1B
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
The malware issues an HTTP GET request to the following Google public DNS IP, which takes a
few seconds to complete, causing the program to pause its activity temporarily.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
This is used as a
method to avoid detection, by delaying further exploitation:
• hxxp://8.8.8[.]8/<Random Path>
• User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; Win32; WinHttp.WinHttpRequest.5)
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Recommendations & Additional Resources
Visa recommends clients take the following actions to mitigate against these threats:
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text: • Institute recurring checks in local networks for IOCs provided in this report.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
• Verify the implementation of required security patches: Payment Card Industry Data Security
Standard (PCI DSS) requires that all system components and software are protected from known
vulnerabilities by installing security patches.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Visit the Payment Card Industry Security Standards
Council (PCI SSC) website for more information.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text: • Regularly scan and test eCommerce sites for vulnerabilities or malware.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Hire a trusted
professional or service provider with a reputation of security to secure the eCommerce
environment.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text: Ask questions and require a report of what was done.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Trust, but verify the steps
taken by the company you hire.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
• Consider using a fully-hosted checkout solution where customers enter their payment details
on another webpage hosted by that checkout solution, separate from the merchant’s site.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
This is
the most secure way to protect the merchant and their customers from eCommerce skimming
malware.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Hosted checkout forms embedded inline on the merchant’s checkout page, such as Visa
Checkout, are another secure option.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
• Use a Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) validated third-party service
provider to store, process or transmit cardholder data.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Criminals commonly target merchant
websites that process payment data.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
When merchants use a validated and secure service provider,
risk exposure for CNP fraud and compromise decreases.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
A list of validated, registered service
providers is available on the Global Registry of Service Providers.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
• Comply consistently with industry security standards, such as the Payment Card Industry Data
Security Standard (PCI DSS), including the PCI Best Practices for Securing e-Commerce, January
2017.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf
fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Visa Public February 2019Visa Public
Visa Payment Fraud Disruption
• Set up a Web Application Firewall to block suspicious and malicious requests from reaching the
website.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text: There are options that are free, simple to use, and practical for small merchants.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf
fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text: Limit access to the administrative portal and accounts to those who need them.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
• Require strong administrative passwords (use a password manager for best results) and enable
two-factor authentication.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf
fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
Regularly ensure shopping cart, other services, and all software are upgraded or patched to
the latest versions to keep attackers out.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
• Monitor for suspicious activity—create and regularly check logs and receive alerts if changes to
the site are made.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text: • Ensure staff are trained in security best practices and follow the designated procedures.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
If a merchant suspects a compromise, they should contact their acquiring bank immediately for guidance
on next steps and to ensure compliance with all Visa investigation and compliance guidelines.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text:
For more
information, refer to the What to Do If Compromised (WTDIC) guide.
source: fin6-cybercrime-group-expands-threat-To-ecommerce-merchants.pdf

text: Navigating the MAZE: Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents   Threat Research Navigating the MAZE: Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: IncidentsJeremy Kennelly, Kimberly Goody, Joshua Shilko May 07, 202021 min read |    Last updated: Nov 24, 2022 RansomwareThreat ResearchTargeted ransomware incidents have brought a threat of disruptive and destructive attacks to organizations across industries and geographies.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: FireEye Mandiant Threat Intelligence has previously documented this threat in our investigations of trends across ransomware incidents, FIN6 activity, implications for OT networks, and other aspects of post-compromise ransomware deployment.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Since November 2019, we’ve seen the MAZE ransomware being used in attacks that combine targeted ransomware use, public exposure of victim data, and an affiliate model.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Malicious actors have been actively deploying MAZE ransomware since at least May 2019.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The ransomware was initially distributed via spam emails and exploit kits before later shifting to being deployed post-compromise.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Multiple actors are involved in MAZE ransomware operations, based on our observations of alleged users in underground forums and distinct tactics, techniques, and procedures across Mandiant incident response engagements.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Actors behind MAZE also maintain a public-facing website where they post data stolen from victims who refuse to pay an extortion fee.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The combination of these two damaging intrusion outcomes—dumping sensitive data and disrupting enterprise networks—with a criminal service makes MAZE a notable threat to many organizations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This blog post is based on information derived from numerous Mandiant incident response engagements and our own research into the MAZE ecosystem and operations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant Threat Intelligence will be available to answer questions on the MAZE ransomware threat in a May 21 webinar.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: VictimologyWe are aware of more than 100 alleged MAZE victims reported by various media outlets and on the MAZE website since November 2019.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These organizations have been primarily based in North America, although victims spanned nearly every geographical region.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Nearly every industry sector including manufacturing, legal, financial services, construction, healthcare, technology, retail, and government has been impacted demonstrating that indiscriminate nature of these operations (Figure 1).Figure 1: Geographical and industry distribution of alleged MAZE victimsMultiple Actors Involved in MAZE Ransomware Operations IdentifiedMandiant identified multiple Russian-speaking actors who claimed to use MAZE ransomware and were seeking partners to fulfill different functional roles within their teams.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Additional information on these actors is available to Mandiant Intelligence subscribers.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: A panel used to manage victims targeted for MAZE ransomware deployment has a section for affiliate transactions.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This activity is consistent with our assessment that MAZE operates under an affiliate model and is not distributed by a single group.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Under this business model, ransomware developers will partner with other actors (i.e. affiliates) who are responsible for distributing the malware.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: In these scenarios, when a victim pays the ransom demand, the ransomware developers receive a commission.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Direct affiliates of MAZE ransomware also partner with other actors who perform specific tasks for a percentage of the ransom payment.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This includes partners who provide initial access to organizations and pentesters who are responsible for reconnaissance, privilege escalation and lateral movement—each of which who appear to work on a percentage-basis.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, in some cases, actors may be hired on a salary basis (vs commission) to perform specific tasks such as determining the victim organization and its annual revenues.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This allows for specialization within the cyber criminal ecosystem, ultimately increasing efficiency, while still allowing all parties involved to profit.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Figure 2: MAZE ransomware panelMAZE
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Initially Distributed via Exploit Kits and Spam CampaignsMAZE ransomware was initially distributed directly via exploit kits and spam campaigns through late 2019.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: For example, in November 2019, Mandiant observed multiple email campaigns delivering Maze ransomware primarily to individuals at organizations in Germany and the United States, although a significant number of emails were also delivered to entities in Canada, Italy, and South Korea.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These emails used tax, invoice, and package delivery themes with document attachments or inline links to documents which download and execute Maze ransomware.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: On November 6 and 7, a Maze campaign targeting Germany delivered macro-laden documents using the subject lines “Wichtige informationen uber Steuerruckerstattung” and “1&1 Internet AG - Ihre Rechnung 19340003422 vom 07.11.19” (Figure 3).
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Recipients included individuals at organizations in a wide range of industries, with the Financial Services, Healthcare, and Manufacturing sectors being targeted most frequently.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These emails were sent using a number of malicious domains created with the registrant address gladkoff1991@yandex.ru.Figure 3: German-language lureOn November 8, a campaign delivered Maze primarily to Financial Services and Insurance organizations located in the United states.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These emails originated from a compromised or spoofed account and contained an inline link to download a Maze executable payload.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: On November 18 and 19, a Maze campaign targeted individuals operating in a range of industries in the United States and Canada with macro documents using phone bill and package delivery themes (Figure 4 and Figure 5).
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These emails used the subjects “Missed package delivery” and "Your AT&T wireless bill is ready to view" and were sent using a number of malicious domains with the registrant address abusereceive@hitler.rocks.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, this registrant address was also used to create multiple Italian-language domains towards the end of November 2019.Figure 4: AT&T email lureFigure 5: Canada Post email lureShift to Post-Compromise Distribution Maximizes ImpactActors using MAZE have increasingly shifted to deploying the ransomware post-compromise.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This methodology provides an opportunity to infect more hosts within a victim’s environment and exfiltrate data, which is leveraged to apply additional pressure on organizations to pay extortion fees.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, in at least some cases, the actors behind these operations charge an additional fee, in addition to the decryption key, for the non-release of stolen data.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Although the high-level intrusion scenarios preceding the distribution of MAZE ransomware are broadly similar, there have been notable variations across intrusions that suggest attribution to distinct teams.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Even within these teams, the cyber criminals appear to be task-oriented meaning that one operator is not responsible for the full lifecycle.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The following sections highlight the TTPs seen in a subset of incidents and serve to illustrate the divergence that may occur due to the fact that numerous, disparate actors are involved in different phases of these operations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, the time between initial compromise to encryption has also been widely varied, from weeks to many months.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Initial CompromiseThere are few clear patterns for intrusion vector across analyzed MAZE ransomware incidents.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This is consistent with our observations of multiple actors who use MAZE soliciting partners with network access.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The following are a sample of observations from several Mandiant incident response engagements:A user downloaded a malicious resume-themed Microsoft Word document that contained macros which launched an IcedID payload, which was ultimately used to execute an instance of BEACON.An actor logged into an internet-facing system via RDP.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The account used to grant initial access was a generic support account.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: It is unclear how the actor obtained the account's password.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor exploited a misconfiguration on an Internet-facing system.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This access enabled the actor to deploy tools to pivot into the internal network.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor logged into a Citrix web portal account with a weak password.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This authenticated access enabled the actor to launch a Meterpreter payload on an internal system.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Establish Foothold & Maintain PresenceThe use of legitimate credentials and broad distribution of BEACON across victim environments appear to be consistent approaches used by actors to establish their foothold in victim networks and to maintain presence as they look to meet their ultimate objective of deploying MAZE ransomware.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Despite these commonplace behaviors, we have observed an actor create their own domain account to enable latter-stage operations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Across multiple incidents, threat actors deploying MAZE established a foothold in victim environments by installing BEACON payloads on many servers and workstations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Web shells were deployed to an internet-facing system.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The system level access granted by these web shells was used to enable initial privilege escalation and the execution of a backdoor.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Intrusion operators regularly obtained and maintained access to multiple domain and local system accounts with varying permissions that were used throughout their operations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor created a new domain account and added it to the domain administrators group.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Escalate PrivilegesAlthough Mandiant has observed multiple cases where MAZE intrusion operators employed Mimikatz to collect credentials to enable privilege escalation, these efforts have also been bolstered in multiple cases via use of Bloodhound, and more manual searches for files containing credentials.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Less than two weeks after initial access, the actor downloaded and interacted with an archive named mimi.zip, which contained files corresponding to the credential harvesting tool Mimikatz.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: In the following days the same mimi.zip archive was identified on two domain controllers in the impacted environment.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The actor attempted to find files with the word “password” within the environment.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Additionally, several archive files were also created with file names suggestive of credential harvesting activity.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The actor attempted to identify hosts running the KeePass password safe software.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Across multiple incidents, the Bloodhound utility was used, presumably to assess possible methods of obtaining credentials with domain administrator privileges.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Actors primarily used Procdump and Mimikatz to collect credentials used to enable later stages of their intrusion.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, both Bloodhound and PingCastle were also used, presumably to enable attackers' efforts to understand the impacted organization's Active Directory configuration.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: In this case the responsible actors also attempted to exfiltrate collected credentials to multiple different cloud file storage services.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: ReconnaissanceMandiant has observed a broad range of approaches to network, host, data, and Active Directory reconnaissance across observed MAZE incidents.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The varied tools and approaches across these incidents maybe best highlights the divergent ways in which the responsible actors interact with victim networks.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: In some intrusions, reconnaissance activity occurred within three days of gaining initial access to the victim network.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The responsible actor executed a large number of reconnaissance scripts via Cobalt Strike to collect network, host, filesystem, and domain related information.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Multiple built-in Windows commands were used to enable network, account, and host reconnaissance of the impacted environment, though the actors also supplied and used Advanced IP Scanner and Adfind to support this stage of their operations.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Preliminary network reconnaissance has been conducted using a batch script named '2.bat' which contained a series of nslookup commands.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The output of this script was copied into a file named '2.txt'.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The actor exfiltrated reconnaissance command output data and documents related to the IT environment to an attacker-controlled FTP server via an encoded PowerShell script.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Over a period of several days, an actor conducted reconnaissance activity using Bloodhound, PowerSploit/PowerView (Invoke-ShareFinder), and a reconnaissance script designed to enumerate directories across internal hosts.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor employed the adfind tool and a batch script to collect information about their network, hosts, domain, and users.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The output from this batch script (2adfind.bat) was saved into an archive named 'ad.7z' using an instance of the 7zip archiving utility named 7.exe.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor used the tool smbtools.exe to assess whether accounts could login to systems across the environment.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor collected directory listings from file servers across an impacted environment.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Evidence of data exfiltration was observed approximately one month later, suggesting that the creation of these directory listings may have been precursor activity, providing the actors with data they may have used to identify sensitive data for future exfiltration.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Lateral MovementAcross the majority of MAZE ransomware incidents lateral movement was accomplished via Cobalt Strike BEACON and using previously harvested credentials.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Despite this uniformity, some alternative tools and approaches were also observed.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Attackers relied heavily on Cobalt Strike BEACON to move laterally across the impacted environment, though they also tunneled RDP using the ngrok utility, and employed tscon to hijack legitimate rdp sessions to enable both lateral movement and privilege escalation.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The actor moved laterally throughout some networks leveraging compromised service and user accounts obtained from the system on which they gained their initial foothold.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This allowed them to obtain immediate access to additional systems.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Stolen credentials were then used to move laterally across the network via RDP and to install BEACON payloads providing the actors with access to nearly one hundred hosts.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor moved laterally using Metasploit and later deployed a Cobalt Strike payload to a system using a local administrator account.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: At least one actor attempted to perform lateral movement using EternalBlue in early and late 2019; however, there is no evidence that these attempts were successful.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Complete MissionThere was evidence suggesting data exfiltration across most analyzed MAZE ransomware incidents.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: While malicious actors could monetize stolen data in various way (e.g. sale in an underground forum, fraud), actors employing MAZE are known to threaten the release of stolen data if victim organizations do not pay an extortion fee.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor has been observed exfiltrating data to FTP servers using a base64-encoded PowerShell script designed to upload any files with .7z file extensions to a predefined FTP server using a hard-coded username and password.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: This script appears to be a slight variant of a script first posted to Microsoft TechNet in 2013.A different base64-encoded PowerShell command was also used to enable this functionality in a separate incident.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Actors deploying MAZE ransomware have also used the utility WinSCP to exfiltrate data to an attacker-controlled FTP server.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor has been observed employing a file replication utility and copying the stolen data to a cloud file hosting/sharing service.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Prior to deploying MAZE ransomware threat actors employed the 7zip utility to archive data from across various corporate file shares.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: These archives were then exfiltrated to an attacker-controlled server via FTP using the WinSCP utility.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: In addition to data theft, actors deploy MAZE ransomware to encrypt files identified on the victim network.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Notably, the aforementioned MAZE panel has an option to specify the date on which ransom demands will double, likely to create a sense of urgency to their demands.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Five days after data was exfiltrated from a victim environment the actor copied a MAZE ransomware binary to 15 hosts within the victim environment and successfully executed it on a portion of these systems.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Attackers employed batch scripts and a series to txt files containing host names to distribute and execute MAZE ransomware on many servers and workstations across the victim environment.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: An actor deployed MAZE ransomware to tens of hosts, explicitly logging into each system using a domain administrator account created earlier in the intrusion.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Immediately following the exfiltration of sensitive data, the actors began deployment of MAZE ransomware to hosts across the network.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: In some cases, thousands of hosts were ultimately encrypted.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: The encryption process proceeded as follows:A batch script named start.bat was used to execute a series of secondary batch scripts with names such as xaa3x.bat or xab3x.bat.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Each of these batch scripts contained a series of commands that employed the copy command, WMIC, and PsExec to copy and execute a kill script (windows.bat) and an instance of MAZE ransomware (sss.exe) on hosts across the impacted environmentNotably, forensic analysis of the impacted environment revealed MAZE deployment scripts targeting ten times as many hosts as were ultimately encrypted.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: ImplicationsBased on our belief that the MAZE ransomware is distributed by multiple actors, we anticipate that the TTPs used throughout incidents associated with this ransomware will continue to vary somewhat, particularly in terms of the initial intrusion vector.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: For more comprehensive recommendations for addressing ransomware, please refer to our Ransomware Protection and Containment Strategies blog post and the linked white paper.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Mandiant Security Validation ActionsOrganizations can validate their security controls against more than 20 MAZE-specific actions with Mandiant Security Validation.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html

text: Please see our Headline Release Content Updates – April 21, 2020 on the Mandiant Security Validation Customer Portal for more information.
source: Navigating the MAZE_ Tactics, Techniques and Procedures Associated With MAZE Ransomware Incidents _ Mandiant.html
